conclusion: The problem involves calculating the maximum power consumed by a resistor R in a circuit with a circular coil placed in a uniform magnetic field. The coil has N=200 turns, an area S=1 m^2, a resistance r=10 Ω, and is connected to an external resistor R=50 Ω. The magnetic field varies linearly with time as shown in the graph.
The graph shows the magnetic field B (in T) varying linearly with time t (in s). At t=0, B=0.2 T, and at t=4 s, B=0.4 T. The slope of the line is constant.
The power consumed by a resistor is given by P = I^2 R, where I is the current in the circuit and R is the resistance of the resistor.
The emf induced in the coil is given by Faraday's law of induction: 𝓔 = -N (ΔΦ / Δt), where ΔΦ is the change in magnetic flux and Δt is the time interval.
The magnetic flux Φ is given by Φ = B · S, where B is the magnetic field and S is the area of the coil.

premise: From the graph, B changes from 0.2 T to 0.4 T over 4 seconds. S = 1 m^2.
conclusion: The change in magnetic flux ΔΦ is ΔB · S = (0.4 T - 0.2 T) · 1 m^2 = 0.2 Wb.
The induced emf is 𝓔 = -N (ΔΦ / Δt) = -200 · (0.2 Wb / 4 s) = -10 V. The magnitude of the emf is 10 V.

premise: The coil has resistance r=10 Ω, and the external resistor has resistance R=50 Ω.
conclusion: The total resistance in the circuit is R_total = r + R = 10 Ω + 50 Ω = 60 Ω.
The current in the circuit is I = 𝓔 / R_total = 10 V / 60 Ω = 1/6 A.
The power consumed by the resistor is P = I^2 R = (1/6 A)^2 · 50 Ω = (1/36) · 50 W = 50/36 W = 25/18 W ≈ 1.39 W.
